div.p: 1. III:45 Shower Bath

Heard Mr Little from John. 15.12. [“]This is my commandment that ye love one another, as I have loved you— 13. Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends. 14 Ye are my friends, if ye do whatsoever I command you.” It was a communion Sermon, and the duties of Christian benevolence were duly and emphatically recommended— The communion was afterwards administered, in which I participated— In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker; from Exodus 20.8. “Remember the Sabbath day to keep it Holy”— In commenting upon this text, Mr Baker indulged his zeal beyond the bounds of discretion— He had preached on the same text this morning, and this was only a remnant of his discourse— He considered as violations of the command to keep the Sabbath holy, all attention to worldly concerns, and declaimed against Sunday travelling Steamboats and Stages, buying and selling—writing Letters and settling accounts—reading of newspapers, novels or books upon any other than religious subjects. He particularly declaimed against persons of distinguished consideration in Society for setting bad examples in this respect, and said that the Nation’s guest himself who was here two years since shewed in this respect that he had more regard for his own convenience, than for his God— I listened to all this very patiently and with my own opinions, as they were before— The extreme heat of the weather prevented me from attending in the Evening at Mr Little’s— He had given notice that a Sermon would be preached, and a collection taken up for the benefit of the Colonization Society.
2. III:30. Shower Bath— Walk a field and in the Garden.

Coll. Thayer the Superintendent of the Academy at West-Point, came to make as he said a confidential communication, relating to the condition of that Institution— The annual Report of the visitors, this year is highly favourable; as it has been heretofore— He said this was correct, so far as the examination of the visitors extended; which was only to the studies of the Cadets, and their acquirements in Science. But he regretted to say the moral condition of the Institution was not so favourable. That a habit of drinking had become very prevalent among them; and unless something effectual could be done to repress it, the Academy instead of proving a Seminary of accomplished education would usher into the world a large proportion of its pupils, even then vicious and prone to ruin and destruction— I asked him if these practices had been of long standing— He said not in much extent— That the Classes being arranged according to their merit, the head of each Class possessed an influence almost boundless over his associates— That heretofore the heads of the Classes have usually been distinguished for their good conduct as much as for their talents. That the reverse has happened with the class now recently graduated— That a young man from this District named Maynadier, was at the head of the Class— But with fine talents was of very loose morals, much addicted to drinking; avowing it, as a right to be asserted and maintained by every youth of Spirit, and encouraging and stimulating others to the same practice— This has now become so common that no small number of the Cadets are in danger of dating their utter ruin from their connection with the Academy. They have introduced a System of Stratagems for procuring liquor, and drinking, with faces averted from each other, that they may not testify one against an other— The Coll. spoke also of the practice of trying the Cadets by Court-Martial, as very objectionable— The Superintendent being required to prefer the charges against the culprit, and thereby placed in the attitude of a party against his own pupils— And the Court Martial consisting of the Officers and Instructors at the Academy, always parties when the
charges, are for violations of the discipline of the Academy, as they almost always are. I requested Coll Thayer to put the substance of these representations in the form of a written Statement, and to leave it with me— As to the regulation, excluding from admission persons infected with contagious disease, I recommended that hereafter it should be executed without requiring an exposure of absolute nakedness— Mr Anderson the Comptroller came in as Coll. Thayer went out: still very much exasperated at the exclusion of his Son, and incensed at the order for a naked examination— He now complained that there had been extraordinary rigour used with his Son; said he was informed Mr ClaysSon, and a youth named Willis had been subsequently admitted without submitting to the naked examination— That a report had been circulated, that the reason why his Son had refused to be examined was that he had an infectious disease—which he said was a foul calumny— On the list of the Candidates for admission, with the remark upon the issue of their examination, those who refused the naked inspection were marked with the word declined—which Mr Anderson said was unfair— That the word would be understood as if they had declined the examination of their literary qualifications, which they had not. His Son having passed that examination, without committing a single error— He also said he had been informed that Dr Wheaton had left the Point, because he would not execute this order for a naked examination— The judge was indeed under so much irritation, that I had a task to keep myself entirely cool— He also asked me, whether I had come to a determination upon the case of the Ex-Cadet Hughes. I said I had not, and should wish to consult with the Secretary of War, before forming it— He spoke too of my Letter to him and the fifth Auditor concerning my old Accounts, which he said they would answer in the course of the week— Mr. Brent spoke of despatches recently received, and which he had sent me, from Mr Gallatin, Mr Brown, and from T. L. L. Brent the Chargé d’Affaires at Lisbon. Mr Weightman the Mayor, and Mr Goldsborough came as a Committee from the Citizens who have determined on a celebration of Independence day—requesting me to join in the procession and attend the Oration to be delivered at Dr Lowrie’s Church. The House of Representatives having passed some order that their Hall at the Capitol should no longer be used for that purpose. I promised to attend. Mr Weightman spoke about the Salary for a City Surveyor— I told him I could find no Law for it— Mr Wheaton brought a Certificate from Doctors and Huntt, that he has the scars of several wounds received in the Revolutionary War, and recommending him for a pension— He repeated his distressing necessities, and says his difficulty at the War Department is that he cannot furnish cotemporary testimony of his wounds, all those who could have testified to them being dead— Mr Frye came, and mentioned his account as Guardian to Thomas J Hellen, Letters for which guardianship he has taken out since the death of Mr Thomas Cook. Mr Southard came with several accounts of Marshal, Jailor and Surgeon, for keeping the negroes at Norfolk Virginia, whom he is sending to Africa— He also read me a Letter which he has received from Mr Joshua Sands, about his claim to a part of the Navy-Yard Lands at Brooklyn— In the trial of the title Mr Sands wishes to be the defendant I thought it would be advisable to take the opinion of the Attorney General— The heat of this day has been overpowering. Fahrenheit at 95. The Sun before nine this morning killed my seedling pot Apple-tree N. 6. the most promising of those that had come up. I passed the day in a state of compulsive idleness.
3. III:30. Boat Bath— Antoine with me— Garden walk

The Ex-Cadet Hughes called this morning, and stated that it was highly important to him to obtain an immediate decision upon his application for a Commission. He stated that he had gone through a course of Education for the Military Profession— That he was unfitted for any other— That to lose the Commission for which he had been preparing, would be ruin to him— That he acquiesced in the decision of the Court-Martial against him, but hoped that his dismission from the Academy would be considered a punishment sufficiently severe for his offence— He asked therefore for a Commission, according to his rank in the Class, and if that could not be obtained, he then requested a Commission immediately after those of his Class— I told him that I would consider of his case, and let him know my determination shortly— Coll. Jones the Adjutant General was here, with a Letter of Resignation of Assistant Surgeon J. Wallace, to take effect from the 31st. of August next, which Jones said was conformable to usage, and to which I agreed— Mr Rush called and read me a Letter from himself to C. J. Ingersoll upon the subject of naturalizing foreigners— He is averse to all Laws restrictive of naturalization, and would confer the rights of a native citizen to every foreigner from the day of his setting his
foot upon our soil— With this opinion I do not exactly concur— He also took with him the Letter from MrC. Dorsey, concerning my opinions upon the projected amendments to the Constitution of the United States for taking the Election away from the House of Representatives— I told Mr Rush distinctly what my opinions were— That I had expressed speculative opinions favourable to an amendment of the provisions in the Constitution, for the primary Election of President and Vice-President— In the Constitutional organization of the Electoral Colleges— I had thought it would be more conformable to the analogy of the other parts of the Constitution, if the whole Union should be divided, into Election Districts— Each District to chuse one member of the House of Representatives for each Congress, and one Elector at each Presidential Election, and that the Legislature of each State should elect the two additional Electors— I had expressed the belief that this would be an improvement— I still inclined to the same belief. But I never have believed or said any thing to indicate the belief that in the only contingency which assigns the Election to the House of Representatives, it ought to be taken from them and given to another body— For setting aside all reference to the last, or to the next Election. I thought in the peculiar contingency of a divided vote in the electoral Colleges, without majority for any one Candidate, the House of Representatives, was of all others the body peculiarly fitted for making the Selection. Being the popular branch of the Legislature— They would generally make the choice most pleasing to the People; and having a participation with the President in the enactment of Laws, they would be most likely to harmonize with a President chosen by themselves than by others— But I further said that the Constitution had left the trust of making Amendments to the two Houses of Congress without admitting the co-operation of the President— It was therefore doubtful to me whether the President could with propriety recommend to them any Amendment— But I had no doubt whatever that there would have been great impropriety in my recommending such an Amendment, after the circumstances under which I had myself been elected by the House— For I could not have done it without giving countenance to those base aspersions upon which the amendment mongers had rested all their cause— I thought therefore there could be no public benefit, and there might be some inconvenience in promulgating my opinions on these subjects— Mr Rush said he would write to Mr Dorsey accordingly.— The Count de Menou called here just before dinner, and mentioned that he had passed the Sunday at Philadelphia, at the same house where Mrs Adams lodged— That he left her well yesterday morning intending to proceed immediately to New-York— The Count, General Macomb, Coll. Thayer, Coll Roberdau, and Mr Frye, dined with us— The whole day was one of the hottest I ever suffered— Fahrenheit in my chamber at 90—and scarcely air to breathe— The fourth of my seedling apple-trees died— All the Silk-worm moths which we have had are now also dead—
4. III:30.— Independence day— Boat Bath with John—

I had received notice last Evening, that the Literary, Scientific and Military Gymnasium of Georgetown, a School, kept by James D. Cobb—would tender me a salute in front of the house at seven O’Clock this morning. They came about eight and fired several rounds of their powder— Mr Robert Potter of North-Carolina came and took his Letters of Recommendation from Governor H. G. Burton which he had sent me, last Evening, with an intimation that he wanted fifty or sixty dollars to get home— He said he was afraid there had been an impropriety in the application he had made— I said there was no impropriety in that; but I did not perceive the propriety of my furnishing him with money. He then asked for the Letters of Recommendation which he had sent me, and I returned them to him— The notification had been that the procession would be formed this morning at ten O’Clock— But the Baltimore, Marion Company of Light Infantry were expected, and did not arrive till near Noon. I joined in the procession, and Mr Rush, Mr Southard, and Marshal Ringgold rode with me— The performances were at Dr Laurie’s Church. An introductory prayer by him— The Declaration of Independence, read by Dr Sim, and the Oration by C. S. Coxe— The House was scarcely filled. After this there was sung an Ode or Hymn— I returned home, escorted by Major Andrews and his troop
of horse, and received visitors, that is, the whole population, from one till three— The Marion Rifle Company, from Baltimore, were all introduced to me individually; by their Captain Branson— About 3. I retired to my chamber, and after dinner took a ride with Miss Roberdeau, and Mary and Johnson Hellen— There were two light Showers about 5 in the afternoon, with a subsequent breeze which refreshed the atmosphere— The day had for the first time a three fold interest, of glory, of joy and of melancholy which mingled in all my recollections— As the day of Independence— As my Son John’s birth-day, and as the day of my father’s decease—
5. III:30. Boat Bath with Antoine— Garden walk—

The Night was again intensely hot— Slept little—and about Midnight I awaked with a severe spasm in the toes of my left foot— The weather has a violent effect in my nervous system, and I find myself as if threatened with deadly cramps— They warn me from the river: notwithstanding which, I took my morning bath, and swam about a quarter of an hour in the Channel— Mansfield was a young self-introduced man from Virginia, applying for an appointment as a Cadet— I told him it was too late for the present year, and advised him to make his application for the next at the War Department in writing. Mr Southard came for directions respecting the Court-Martial, to be called for the trial of Brevet Lieutt. Colonel Richard Smith and Lieutenant Joseph C. Hall— It must be summoned by the War Department— There not being a sufficient number of Officers of the Marine Corps, disposable and competent for the trial— I was making some observations upon the draught of the Charges when Mr Bouligny came in with a bundle of papers, and an application from the Corporation of New-Orleans for some lands within the City belonging to the Public, and of which they wish for a grant— Mr Brent was here at the same time, with an application in behalf of a man in jail upon several indictments for assault and battery— The application was from his Mother, and judge Cranch recommended a compliance with it. But there was no Petition from the man himself— Mr Brent however took the papers, and shortly after sent me a petition from the man; and I signed an order for his discharge. Captain Burch of the Army; brought a Letter of introduction from Mr Southard, being a native of New-Jersey. I sent for Major Nourse, and mentioned to him my disposition to give the Ex-Cadet Hughes a Commission; but of a date subsequent to those of his Class— He said Coll. Thayer had told him that independent of the transactions upon which Hughes was tried and sentenced to be dismissed, his conduct had in other respects been very exceptionable— That if I wished it, he would report particularly to me concerning it— Nourse added that there had never been an instance of a Cadet sentenced to be dismissed and afterwards obtaining a Commission— I desired him to request Coll. Thayer, to report to me in writing upon the character and conduct of Hughes— Dr. Niles called again to ascertain if he could obtain a Commission as a Surgeon in the Navy, with permission to reside at Paris as a Literary Agent for the Department, or for the Government generally to procure beds, such as might from time to time be wanted, and to give advices relating to Literature and Science— I told him I had conferred upon the subject with the Secretary of the Navy. He thought there were no supernumerary Surgeons— None who could be spared from their appropriate duties— He then said that the Office of U.S. Consul at Paris and that of Agent of Claims, would shortly be vacant, and asked if in that event he could be considered as a Candidate for the place. I said certainly— But that it was doubtful whether Congress would continue to make an appropriation for an Agent of Claims at Paris, after the present agent should vacate the Office— Coll. Thomas Randall who has returned from his visit to Florida called for a visit— He said he came direct from Tallahassee, and proposed to return and finally settle in the Territory, next Fall— Mary Roberdeau left us, and returned home this Evening— My Son John is unwell; suffering with this unrelenting heat— I received a Letter from my wife dated at New-York on Tuesday Morning and wrote to her— A Letter from my Son George to her, dated last Saturday, and received yesterday, gives a more favourable account of his health, and says that his Physicians have given him permission to go out and pass the fourth at Quincy, upon condition of his remaining there in quiet—
6. IV— Boat Bath with Antoine— Garden— 2. Quincy Walnuts came up the 4th.

Major Elkins of the Militia, came this Morning to inform me that the Rifle Company from Baltimore, who were going this day to visit Georgetown, wished to pay me a marching salute, on their way; and he afterwards came to mention the time, between half past eleven and Noon— They accordingly came, and I received their marching Salute. They were escorted by several of the Militia Officers of the District— They dined at Georgetown and in the afternoon commenced their march homeward—on passing by the house they again gave it a Salute of three Cheers— Coll. Thomas came and kept me about two hours in electioneering political conversation, to which I was little more than a listener. He has been to Richmond, Virginia, upon business of his own, and is returning to New-York. He said little of Virginia, but much of men and things in New-York— Told me of numerous conversations with Governor Clinton, and many of his friends, and of other persons, all having reference to electioneering— The whole tendency of his Conversation was to satisfy me that he was disposed to make himself agreeable—and it manifested that knowledge of the world, in which many of the New-York politicians are proficients— Mr Southard had sent me last Evening Letters from Commodore Chauncey from which it appeared that the question about the title to the Navy-Yard, at Brooklyn, had festered into a mob pulling down the fence which he had erected, and a personal affray between him, and two of Joshua Sands’ssons, in which he complains of having been outrageously assaulted, but for which he has been sued, and bound over to keep the Peace. He asks for instructions— Upon which I desired they might be, that no further resistance of force should be made to any thing Sands or any other of the claimants might do on the ground; but that an action of trespass should be instituted against them—for pulling down the fence, by which the title can be tried; and that Lieutenant Sands should be tried by a Court Martial for his assault upon Chauncey— Mr Southard suggested the expediency of immediately suspending Lieutenant Sands from duty, to which I assented. I endorsed also an order upon his Letter relating to the charges against Coll. Smith and Lieutenant Hall; of the Marine Corps, directing that a Court-Martial should be convened by the War Department, consisting of Officers of the Army, together with two from the Marine Corps. Isaac Adams of Baltimore, came with a Petition from John Gooding of that place, that a Noli Prosequi may be entered to a prosecution against him for the violation of the Statutes against the Slave-trade— He had also a recommendation to that effect from several very respectable Citizens of Baltimore; and Adams appealed to my compassionate feelings for this man, who he said had once been in flourishing circumstances, and was meritorious in privateering during the late War; but was now ruined, and had a wife and eleven children, dependent upon him for bread. I took the papers, and said I would do for his relief whatever might be in my power. Mr Clarke the Clerk of the House of Representatives, called to take leave—going to-morrow to visit his family in Pennsylvania— He returned a few days since from an excursion to New-York, where he has been to procure Stationary for the House— Mr Daniel Brent called with a Commission made out for T. Randall as judge of the Middle District of Florida, in the place of Augustus B. Woodward, deceased; but I have not yet received any authentic account of his Death. Major Hamilton came to enquire if I had read the voluminous papers which he sometime since left with me— I had read only part of them, and he said he would call again. I rode this Evening, with Johnson and Mary Hellen, and my Son Charles— John has been quite unwell. An easterly breeze greatly refreshed the atmosphere. This morning, I discovered two trees up, and already in leaf, from the row of Quincy Walnuts planted last November— They undoubtedly came up after the Shower on the 4th. My apple tree N. 2. after a pause of six days is forming a sixth leaf proper— The transplanted tree remains stunted, but is not dead— Both are so feeble that half an hours Sun, or a fresh breeze of wind would kill them— There are now five shoots of Oranges in the Pot where I planted nine, but the first up has for several days ceased to grow.
7. IV. Boat-Bath with Antoine— Swam 20 Minutes— Garden walk.

Mr Knapp introduced as a visitor, Mr Lockwood of New-York. Mr Rush brought a Petition from John Hutchinson, Master of the British Ship William Dawson for a remission of penalty for bringing an excess of Passengers— I gave him two petitions for remissions of penalties, one from Pensacola, and within the competency of the Secretary of the Treasury. The other from New-York, a passenger case the peculiarity of which was that being a British Barque, the measurement at our Custom-house gave her a tonnage of about four per Cent less than her British Register— The usual result being an augmentation, upon the British Register of about the same amount— There was also something remarkable in the phraseology of the Captain’s Affidavit, which excited suspicion— Before granting the petition therefore, I thought proper that some further explanations should be required from the Collector at New-York. Mr Rush read me part of a Letter from C. J. Ingersoll speaking of a German by the name of List, whom he thinks it might be useful to enlist— I was occupied part of this day in reading the proceedings of a Court Martial upon two trials of 2d. Lieutenant J. J. Schuler— My plantations absorb too much of my time— A curiosity has seized me to enumerate the productions of the Earth, growing in the Garden— The whole number of which I this day, made a list exceeds one hundred— I presume there may be about fifty more among the weeds and flowers which have yet escaped me— A daily examination of about one month more would be necessary to make me intimately acquainted with them all— In observing the process of vegetation, the garden has drawn my attention to the growth of my walnuts, of wild cherries, Althea’s and Lilacs, self sown, as well as of some weeds and flowers— I have sown seeds of Strawberries, raspberries and Currants, none of which have yet come up— This day, I strewed in a Quart Tumbler 30 Black Mulberry seeds, and sifted over them fresh Earth, just enough to cover them— I have also preserved in various ways, Cherry, Plum, and Apricot Stones, and Strawberry, Raspberry, Currant, black and red, Gooseberry, and Black Mulberry Seeds, to plant or Sow them next Autumn or Spring— I flatter myself that the knowledge obtained by this idling may hereafter be turned to some useful purpose.
8. IV. Shower Bath.

Showery Morning— Heard Mr Little from Psalm 144.15. “Happy is that people, that is in such a case; yea happy is that people, whose God is the Lord.” an occasional discourse having reference to the recent anniversary of Independence: and in which the peculiar blessings enjoyed by the People of this Country were set forth, without exaggeration, and with a proper homage of gratitude to the dispenser of them. Mr Little gave notice that being personally somewhat indisposed, there would be no evening service at that Church. In the afternoon I heard Mr Baker, from Proverbs 1.20. [“]Wisdom crieth with out; she uttereth her voice in the Streets: 21 She crieth in the chief place of concourse, in the openings of the gates: in the city she uttereth her words, saying 22. How long, ye simple ones, will ye love simplicity? and the scorners delight in their scorning, and fools hate knowledge? 23. Turn you at my reproof: behold I will pour out my spirit unto you, I will make known my words unto you. 24. Because I have called; and ye refused; I have stretched out my hand, and no man regarded: 25. But ye have set at naught all my counsel, and would none of my reproof. 26. I also will laugh at your calamity; I will mock when your fear cometh; 27. When your fear cometh as desolation, and your destruction cometh as a whirlwind; when distress and anguish cometh upon you 28— Then shall they call upon me, but I will not answer; they shall seek me early but they shall not find me.” Mr Baker construes Wisdom to mean Christ; and all the denunciations of this text, as applying to the unconverted, who have not faith in the atonement— After dinner I rode to the Navy-Yard, and Eastern Branch with Mary and Johnson Hellen and Charles— I found myself while at dinner suddenly so hoarse, that I almost lost my voice— This continued all the Evening, and I was unable to speak without pain— The cause of which I could scarcely even conjecture— My Spirits flag with my health. I wrote a short answer to three Letters from D. Webster.
9. IV.— Boat Bath with Antoine— Swam 20 minutes against Tide— Garden—

Major Nourse brought me a Letter from Coll. Thayer, respecting the Ex-Cadet Hughes, and also a Copy of revised Regulations for the Military Academy, which were proposed last Winter by Coll. Thayer and are under Consideration of the Secretary of War— I spoke to Nourse of the impression made on my mind, by the proceedings of the Court-Martial on the two trials of Lieutt. Schuler. He said there was a prejudice against him in the army, and that neither of the Officers who brought the charges against him, stands high in reputation— Judge Anderson introduced to me the two young men named King and Starr, but had no acquaintance with them himself, having first met them in the Anti chamber— Their visit was of mere curiosity— Judge Anderson came again to recommend the application of G. W. Hughes for a Commission, which he urged with great earnestness— The Report of Coll. Thayer is unfavourable to him— On the roll of merit for conduct his name stands 186. in a number of 202—but judge Anderson thought that personal partiality had operated against him, and pleaded the importance to the young man of that profession to which he has been bred—his Youth; and that with regard to any Report of Coll. Thayer against him, he ought to have the opportunity of defending himself. I discussed the subject with him perhaps for an hour, and he recurred again to the late rejection of his Son, for refusing to submit to the inspection of his person naked— The Son returned here last Evening— The judge complained of the expense which it had occasioned him; but said that neither he nor his Son would now on any consideration agree that the Son should enter at the Academy. Mr Rush came for the Petition of John Hutchinson, Master of the British Ship William Dawson, which he had left here, and the order of release from the penalties which he has incurred for bringing an excess of passengers— Dr Niles came and informed me that Mr Southard had declined giving him a Commission as a surgeon in the Navy with permission to reside at Paris but had promised to commissionate him to purchase Books for the Department, if any should be wanted. He also offered me his personal services and gave me a Volume of Statistical Researches upon Paris, and the Department of the Seine. Mr Southard was here, with another Letter from Commodore Chauncey, who has again been prosecuted upon a Statute of the State of New-York, before three Justices of the Peace, who have put Sands in possession of the disputed ground, and have required Chauncey to withdraw his Sentinel from that part of the Yard— Mr Sands has also written to Mr Southard for a copy of his own Letter to him, in order to make a public exposition of the military interposition in this affair. He mentioned also the arrival of the U.S. Schooner Shark at New-York, and of his intention to order her upon a cruize to the Coast of Labrador to look to the fisheries— Mr Bouligny came and introduced judge Bullard of Louisiana, who is travelling for his health— Bouligny spoke also of the application from the Mayor of New-Orleans, respecting certain Lands, which the City Council have advertised for Sale, but which are claimed as belonging to the United States— I had not fully examined the papers, but did, after Mr Bouligny left me, and must take the opinion of the Attorney-General concerning them— Judge Cranch called here this Evening, and gave me three Letters from me to him, written at Newbury-Port dated 14. October. and 8. December 1787. and 16— February 1788. containing my objections to the Constitution of the United States, which was then before the people for consideration— Also a Letter from my father to him, of 10. March 1823—and one of James Lloyd of 10. February 1825— The fortieth year is revolving since my own Letters were written; and now their best use is to teach me a lesson of humility, and of forbearance— I was so sincere, so earnest, so vehement in my opinions, and time has so crumbled them to dust, that I can now see them only as monumental errors— Yet the Spirit was such as even now I have no reason to disclaim— A Spirit of Patriotism of Order and of Benevolence— In the last of the Letters, is an allusion to my own state of mind at the time, more affecting than all my political Speculations.
10. IV: Boat Bath with Antoine— Swam from the Bridge— Garden— Evening Ride—

Mr Brent came for papers relating to an African, who appears to be a subject of the Emperor of Morocco, but is a Slave in Georgia— He procured a Letter to be written for him to the Emperor of Morocco, by whom it was communicated to Mr Mullowny the Consul of the United States at Tangier— He has sent a Translation of it here, with an earnest recommendation that the Government of the United States should purchase the man, and send him home, as a complimentary donation to the Emperor— I requested Mr Brent to write to Georgia, and ascertain the price for which he could be purchased; and if practicable to carry into effect the wish of Mr Mullowny— Dr Watkins called and shewed me a Letter from Govr. Barbour, written at the Bedford Springs. He requested a copy of my printed Letter in answer to the attack of Alexander Smyth in 1822— I found and gave him one, together with a copy of my Letter to H. G. Otis upon the Embargo, as reprinted at Baltimore in 1824— Watkins shewed me also a Letter from J. C. Wright, containing what Watkins thought a lame apology, for another stranger Letter of Wright’s to Edward King of Ohio, from which King as strangely published extracts in a Newspaper. Mr Fendall came from the Department of State, for Mullowny’s Letter, and the enclosures in it which he took. Mr Southard called and took the title Deeds, and all the other papers relating to the contested title to the Navy-Yard at Brooklyn on Long Island: He said he would have an abstract made from them; and a Summary of all the facts in this controversy; to be used hereafter as occasion may require— I received a Letter from my wife at Boston of the 6th. She arrived there the morning of the 5th.— She proposes that George, and Charles who is going to Boston to finish his Law Studies there, should take a small house, and invite Louisa Smith to keep it for them. I talked with Charles about it, and it appeared, to fall in with his inclination— I shall consent to this proposal, with hope, and trust, and great anxiety— In the Evening I rode in the Carriage with Mary Hellen and Charles round by the Capitol and the College.
11. IV:15. Boat Bath with Antoine. Swam from the Bridge.

Mr Catlett of Alexandria, introduced Mr Andrew Gray of New-York, Consignee of a British vessel named the William, William Potts Master which entered at Perth-Amboy from Newry in Ireland— She has been seized for bringing an excess of Passengers, and there was a petition from Potts the Master, and one from this Mr Gray and his partner Harden in behalf of the owners of the vessel for a remission of the penalties and forfeiture— From the Petition of the Captain himself, there appeared to be circumstances in the case of a suspicious nature, and the papers were referred to the Collector of Perth Amboy for a Report— The Report is now received— There was not only an excess of passengers beyond the number allowed by Law, of more than fifty, but there were twenty-three more than he returned, or than appeared, on his license from the British Government; and these 23 he had clandestinely landed and sent to New-York. He attempted to bribe the custom-House Officer by whom his vessel was first boarded; and he made no return of the deaths on board during the passage, as the Law requires— There was among the papers an affidavit of his Surgeon, attesting the universal health of the passengers on their departure, on their arrival, and during the passage, suppressing the fact that there had been a death of one passenger— Under all these circumstances, I declined remitting the penalties and forfeitures— Dr Watkins called and gave me to read a Letter from Jos. Blunt at New-York, with which he was much gratified. Mr Rush was twice here, and chiefly spoke of the case of the British Brig William, and the personal application of Mr Gray— He agreed with me that a remission of the penalty and forfeiture would be altogether unjustifiable in this Case— I am this day three-score years of age— To the giver of all good let me bow in gratitude for the past, and in humble trust for the remnant of my days.
12. IV. Boat Bath with Antoine— Swam from the Bridge—

Mr Martineau is an Engineer concerned in some project for opening a water communication across the isthmus of Florida— He came to enquire if the Government had the design to establish an additional Naval depot, any where South of Norfolk Virginia, and North of Pensacola— I told him there was no such intention for the present— There might be hereafter, but it could be carried into effect only by an Act of Congress. I advised him to see and converse on the subject with the Secretary of the Navy— He told me that he had seen me in England. Mr Rush called and read to me two Letters which he has received from W. H. Crawford one dated in February, and the other in April last, both recommending very earnestly, persons for appointment to Office, and both full of abuse and invective upon me— Crawford is an instance, not solitary of a man whose Passions have thriven upon the decay of his body and mind— Major Nourse called for my decision upon the application of the Ex-Cadet G. W. Hughes for a Commission— I had concluded on much consideration of all the circumstances to grant him one, immediately after the rest of his Class, but Major Nourse pointed me to the Army Regulation N. 1391. expressly declaring that no Cadet dismissed for misconduct shall be commissioned within five years after his Class— I desired the Major therefore to answer his Letter to the Secretary of War, and say that I cannot depart from the Regulation— The three Commissioners for the distribution of the Slave indemnities, met and organized themselves in this City on the 10th. and this morning they visited me together— They are Langdon Cheves, of Pennsylvania, James Pleasants of Virginia, and Henry Seawell of North-Carolina— Mr Edward Livingston of New-Orleans also paid me a visit; being here as an agent for some of the Louisiana claimants. He made some enquiries concerning the state of the Negotiation with the British Government, about Light Houses on the Coast of Florida, and referred to a Letter which he wrote to me on the subject, last Winter— He thinks the matter has not been presented to the British Government in a proper light, to prove to them that the establishment of these Light-Houses, is as much for their interest as for ours— There was this Evening a very heavy thunder gust, which passed to the Northward of the City— All we had of it was a moderate rain. I received a distressing Letter from Mrs Adams, upon our Son George’s health.
13. IV:15. Shower Bath— Walk to the Slashes—and in the Garden.

Hughes the Ex-Cadet came again to renew his application for a Commission. I told him that my own disposition had been favourable to him, but that the Regulation was imperative and prohibitory— He referred to several instances of Commissions which he said had been granted to persons after they had been dismissed from the Academy: but they were not within the prohibition of the regulation. He then said he should be under the necessity of leaving this Country, and of tendering his Services to a foreign Nation; and asked me for a certificate under my signature that he had been educated at the military Academy at West-Point, which I declined, as being altogether unnecessary to authenticate the fact; and equally unusual— Mr Brent called and mentioned Letters received from Mr Brown our Minister at Paris, and from J. J. Appleton Charge d’Affaires at Stockholm— The former on a question concerning the construction of an Article in the Commercial Convention with France— The latter concerning the renewal of the Commercial Treaty with Sweden— I received another Letter of the 9th. from my wife, giving more favourable hopes of the health of my Son George— The day was intensely fervid, and the evening a breathless calm. I had omitted the morning bath in the river for which the tide did not well serve. I took the Shower bath with little effect, and walked in the Slashes towards the deserted College— I picked a few ripe bush blackberries; they are just beginning to ripen, and remained in doubt why this fruit is not cultivated in gardens— The Palma Christi and the Prince’s feather Amaranth are blooming, and I made acquaintance with the Southernwood—Bladder Cetmi, Canna Indica, Bastard Saffron, Ipoma Comoclete, and some
others, neither the names nor the forms of which will dwell upon my memory. My ten walnut trees which have come up in the garden since the 17th. of June live, and have freely put forth leaves. The Poppies have blossomed and gone to seed. The Mustard has done the same. The Lettuce is five feet high, and in full blossom— The wild cherries slow of growth; overshot already by the Althea’s, which came up six weeks later— My observations on the process of vegetation are desultory and confused, and perhaps directed to circumstances of little or no import. None of my plantations of the present Season in the garden have come up— I signed an approval of 8 Lead mine Leases in Missouri— From 73 to 81.
14. IV:15.— Boat Bath with John— Swam from the Bridge— Garden.

Mr Graham brought me two Proclamations for Land Sales which I signed, one for the 3d. Monday of November, of Washington, Mississippi— The other for the first Monday of November, at Palestine, Illinois— I desired him to send me all the Land-Patents prepared for my signature, and about 1000 blanks to be signed before my Northern excursion. Coll. Thayer came and informed me that he proposed leaving the City to-morrow Morning to return to West-Point— He has left here a manuscript Copy of a revised set of regulations for the Academy, which are under examination and must be deliberately considered. He recurred again to the practice of trying the Cadets by Court Martial; and expressed again his opinion that it was of most pernicious tendency— It has first the inconvenience of placing the Superintendent and the pupils in the relations of prosecuting, and criminated parties, upon trial; in which if the prosecutor fails, he is humiliated before his pupil— Secondly, he must generally rely for his testimony upon other Cadets; that is upon the accomplices of the party accused—and thirdly the testimony is of doubtful character, the regard, for truth being on the part of many of the witnesses postponed to the supposed duty of sustaining their fellow Students— I told the Colonel that I had finally refused a Commission to G. W. Hughes; he said it would be a great benefit to the army to be relieved from such an Officer— That his conduct had been bad—his example pernicious—his influence ruinous to other Cadets whom he had inveigled to their ruin, while he had generally contrived to keep himself out of danger— I sent for Mr Pleasonton, to enquire concerning the case of a man named Henry Fry, in prison at Albany for a debt due to the United States, and who has petitioned to be discharged— Pleasonton said he was a purser in the Navy—confined for a balance due on the settlement of his Accounts— He had two bondsmen; the only responsible one of whom, is D. J. Pearce, the Member of Congress from Rhode-Island— Fry was confined at his instance, upon a belief entertained by him that Fry had property to pay the Execution, which however it appears he has not— Pleasonton thought it would be proper to refer Fry’s petitions—for report of the U.S. District Attorney of the Northern District of New-York— Mr Rush sent me another petition from the same Henry Fry, with advice to the same effect— Mr Rush also sent me a Letter from Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn the Collector at Boston, in answer to enquiries, respecting the prospects of the Revenue for the present year. He Reports that the first and second quarter of this year will yield less than the corresponding quarters of the last; but the third and fourth quarters will nearly restore the balance— He estimates the revenue from the Customs at Boston, for the whole year 1826 at less than 12000 dollars short of four Millions. That of 1827 about 150,000 dollars reduced— But New-York will give half a million more— On the whole the prospects are that there will be no additional falling off this year— I directed the removal of J. E. Skaats as keeper of the Light-House at Buffaloe, and the appointment of William Jones in his place— Also the appointment of James Powell as Light-House keeper at Smith’s Island, Virginia, with a Salary of 400 dollars a year— Evening visit from the Count de Menou, who is going on a Tour to Philadelphia— Mary Roberdeau came to pass some days with Mary Hellen. My seedling Pot Apple Tree N. 2. has been this day one Month up. It has now six full formed Apple tree leaves besides the seed leaves. a Seventh is beginning to open— The transplanted tree which came up the 16th. and was transplanted the 21st. of June, has also six leaves and a seventh opening, but is more stunted— This day I first perceived two tap-roots, descending the side of Glass tumbler N. 1. from an Orange seed, buried there the 18th of June— The heat continues overpowering.
15. IV— Shower and Cold Bath—

Heard Mr Little, from Isaiah 45–22. [“]Look unto me, and be ye saved, all the ends of the Earth: for I am God, and there is none else. 23. I have sworn by myself, the word is gone out of my mouth in righteousness and shall not return, That unto me, every knee shall bow, every tongue shall swear. 24. Surely shall one say, in the Lord have I righteousness and strength: even to him shall men come; and all that are incensed, against him shall be ashamed. 25. In the Lord shall all the seed of Israel be justified and shall glory.”— The Sermon was a dissertation upon the Book of Isaiah—which he observed was written before the Greeks had any Literature, and before Rome existed— He observed that the evidence of the authenticity and antiquity of this and the other Books of the Old Testament was unquestionable, and referred to the collection of them by Ezra, and the Septuagint translation under Ptolemy— It is very remarkable, that the influence of these Scriptures upon the moral character and History of mankind dates from this period— The Books of Moses, containing the Law, were locked up in the Ark of the Covenant—was afterwards lost, and in the time of Josiah was again found in the Temple— Its contents were entirely unknown to Josiah when it was found; from which it is clear that no copies of it had been in circulation till then— The historical books were the records of public events, kept by the Priests with the Book of the Law— The Psalms of David were devotional exercises kept in like manner, and the writings of Solomon, were treated with the same respect— How the Books of the Prophets came there does not appear— They were all written shortly before, and during the Assyrian and Babylonian captivity: and most extraordinary books they are— The whole body of the Scriptures was collected by Ezra, upon the building of the second Temple, and the return from the captivity— This was about 480 years before Christ. The Septuagint translation was made about 200 years later— Until the time of the captivity, the influence of the Holy Books was exclusively confined to the tribes of Israel;—and often yielded to neglect, and oblivion, and were often sacrificed to idolatry among them— The last of the prophets and Ezra, were nearly cotemporary but before Herodotus— The astonishing, and it may be said miraculous power of the holy books over the human mind, was much increased by the Greek translation; and it is surprizing that neither Aristotle, nor Plato, nor Xenophon have any allusion to them— The Doctrinal part of Mr Little’s Sermon was as usual unitarianism— He gave notice that during the continuance of the intensely hot weather; the evening Service would be intermitted— Mr Bakers Sermon this afternoon was from Genesis. 6.5. “And God saw that the wickedness of man, was great in the earth and that every imagination of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually.” Mr Baker considered this description of the dispositions of men in the antedeluvian world, as entirely applicable to the present times, and to ourselves. If I could be persuaded that to believe ourselves the vilest of Gods creatures would make us better; I should be more credulous of this creed— I rode round by the Capitol and the College this Evening with my Son John.
16. IV. Boat Bath with Antoine.— Garden— Showers

A Northeast wind cooled the atmosphere, and terminated in cool showers— The water of the river was tepid— As additional to the plants in the garden, Ousley shewed me three young fig-trees which he has planted under the wall, of the Treasury Department yard. Dr. Watkins introduced a young man named Charles Pierce late of Dorchester near Boston, who applies for a Midshipman’s warrant, and brought me Letters of recommendation form Dr T. M. Harris and from E. Everett, with several others to the Secretary of the Navy— D. Brent sent me several Letters received at the Department of State, among which two despatches of 29 and 30. May, from A. Gallatin. One gives an account of the resumption of Conferences with Mr Huskisson, and Mr Addington, of no auspicious character. The other encloses the correspondence relating to the arrest of his Coachman for a breach of the Peace— In this correspondence there is much complimentary varnish; but the substance of it was that Mr Gallatins Coachman had presumed upon his privilege to commit a breach of the peace— That the Police Magistrate, took him by Warrant, in his own stable without regard to the privilege either of the Coachman, or of his Master, that in this practical exposition of regard to the Law of Nations, the Law Officers of the Crown, sustained the Police
Magistrate— That the Privilege of the Minister was totally disregarded; and that Mr Gallatin forbore to insist upon his rights, and contented himself with polite notes from Mr Conant the Magistrate, from Lord Dudley the Secretary of State for foreign Affairs, and from Mr Backhouse his Secretary— He reserved however the question for the consideration of his Government— Mr William Lee was here but a few minutes. Mr Feeter from New-York came with sundry Letters to apply for the office of Collector at Oswegatchie, in behalf of his brother in Law, Matthew Myers— The Office is vacant by the resignation of Aaron Heckley— Mr ThompsonGeneral Porter and Mr Mann are visitors from Pennsylvania— Coll. Roberdeau called to shew me a Letter from one of his friends, and Coll. Ogden is the Secretary to the Commissioners for distributing the Slave indemnities. Watkins called a second time with a Letter from R. Peters junr enclosing one from Jos. R. Ingersoll— I received a Letter of the 12th. from Mrs Adams.
17. IV. Walk to the Slashes— Garden.

Intermitted the morning bath, and walked towards the College— Found some ripe fruit on the Blackberry Bushes— Their seed viewed through a microscope resembles exactly that of the raspberry— The Strawberry seed is the grape seed in miniature— The Gooseberry and current, differ from them all, and a little from each other— One of my Orange seeds buried at the side of a glass Tumbler came up this morning. It has already two tap-roots from two to three inches long, and pushing to the Bottom of the Tumbler— Mr Adams was from North-Carolina, and Claims a Patent right which is contested by another person— I advised him to apply to Dr Thornton or Mr William Elliot at the Patent Office— Mr and Mrs. Howland were visitors from South-Carolina, who first called and left a Message requesting to see me, and afterwards called with a young man whose name I think they said was Hand— Mr Rush came for the papers relating to the case of Henry Leslie, master of the British Barque Trio, who has incurred a penalty for bringing an excess of passengers, beyond the allowance of the Law—Some explanations were requested from the Collector at New-York, an answer from whom was among the papers— I had also some conversation with Mr Rush, upon a new application of Edward Thomson, to be released from prison, and concerning which there were Letters from the Attorney General and Josiah Randall— Mr Rush thought it would not be proper to discharge Thomson for the present— I wrote to Mr T. B. Johnson, who is about to embark for Europe, requesting him to procure and forward to me from the South of France or Italy, some Olives, and Cork Oak Acorns, for cultivation in this Country— He proposes to pass a year or two in those Countries— I rode after dinner with Miss Roberdeau, and Charles— Mary Hellen is unwell— The Ladies were visited this Evening by Mrs Bankhead and Mrs Kuhn—
18. IV. Boat Bath with Antoine— Garden.

A man by the name of Bates this morning met me as I was returning from my river Bath, and said he had a petition for the release of a prisoner to present me, and asked at what hour he should call with it— I told him at ten and he came at that hour— The Prisoner he said was his brother, and he brought two Petitions in his favour, one from Dumfries in Virginia, signed by perhaps 20 names utterly unknown to me, and one signed by five or six names equally unknown in this City— I told him there must be a petition from the prisoner himself—and a recommendation in his favour from the District Attorney or one of the judges— Mr Brent brought several Letters recommending Henry Chipman as judge of the Michigan Territory, in the place of John Hunt, deceased, and as there is a Court to be held in September, I requested Mr Brent to have a Commission made out for Mr Chipman— John Boyle came and introduced himself to me as an acquaintance of Mr Clay’s—an Irishman, who has been residing seventeen years in this country, and is now going to visit his friends in Ireland— He wanted a Passport, and Letters to the Consuls of the United States at Dublin and Belfast, for which I referred him to Mr Brent of the Department of State. General Macomb and Coll Roberdeau, came and introduced
Captain Bates of the Engineers— He has been surveying in North-Carolina, till the party were compelled by bilious fevers to disperse— I had also a visit from Mr Jenifer of Maryland— We had company to dine— MessrsCheves and Pleasants members and Coll. Ogden Secretary to the Slave indemnity Commission, Livingston of Louisiana, Thomson, Porter, Adjutant General, and Mann, Auditor General of Pennsylvania, General Macomb, Colonel Roberdeau, and Captain Bates. Mr Rush and Mr SouthardJudge Randall, D. Brent and Fendall of the Department of State and Mr Frye— Mary Hellen being unwell the Ladies did not dine with us, and Johnson Hellen dined with them— I found this morning a fifth Pennsylvania Walnut up in my Eastern Bed; and a third, fourth and fifth Quincy Walnut up in the Southern bed— Fifteen of these trees are now up— Ten Pennsylvanian—five from Quincy.
19. IV. Walk to the Slashes— Blackberries ripe— Garden— Evening ride.

Mr Varney is a Frenchman who has been long residing in this Country, and who reminded me that he was two or three years since introduced to me by W. S. Smith. He came to say that the Directors of the Chesapeake and Delaware Canal, were much embarrassed, and there was danger that the undertaking would be abandoned— But he said he had foreseen the difficulties with which they are now struggling and had foretold them to me, when he last saw me. But he said he had enabled the State of Pennsylvania to finish their Susquehanna Canal, and he could help the Directors of this Canal through with all their difficulties— His expedient so far as I understood him was to sow locust seeds on the sides of the canal, to consolidate the ground. I referred him to the Secretary of the Treasury for a further explanation of his project, and advised him also to make it known to the directors of the Canal— I sent to Mr Dickins as Secretary to the Columbian Institute to enquire if George Sullivan had been elected a corresponding member of the Institute— I had nominated him for election nearly two years since; and I had received yesterday a Letter from Sullivan enquiring of the result. Dickins came and told me that Sullivan had been elected, but had never been notified of his election— Said he would send me a certificate to-morrow. He also shewed me three draughts of a form of certificate of election, and two devices for Seals which have been prepared but not yet adopted. He had some conversation concerning them, and he left them with me for Consideration— Major Nourse Chief Clerk of the War Department brought me a Letter from Coll Bomford Head of the Ordnance, concerning the adjustment of the Account between the United States, and the State of Pennsylvania, relating to the expenses of the late War— The subject of the visit of Messrs.Thompson, Porter and Mann, to this City— Major Nourse mentioned also a Report received from Coll. Brearley who went with the Creek Indians to select a place of Settlement West of the Mississippi— And also a Letter from Governor Troup of Georgia, upon the subject of arms furnished for the Militia of that State according to an act of Congress. Both these Letters have been sent to the Secretary of War— Johnson Hellen came and introduced Coll. Cook and Mr Brashears, who were about returning to the Country— Mr Rush came with Letters and papers from the Collectors of the Customs at Bristol Rhode Island, Drury and at Petersburg, Virginia Robertson; both of whom, he fears there will be a necessity for removing from Office— He concluded to write to D. J. Pearce the member from Newport, in relation to the Office of Collector at Bristol, and a very peremptory Letter to Mr Robertson himself at Petersburg— Dr Watkins called and shewed me a Letter from Governor Barbour, still at Bedford— After dinner George Thumlert came with some papers relating to his genealogy— He is the Son of a Wurtemberger who came to this Country more than half a century since, and he had applied to me about three years since, for means of communication with his relations in Germany— His object was the same now, and he had a Letter from an Aunt in Pennsylvania, whom he has discovered since his former application— I promised to transmit his enquiries through C. Hughes— I rode this Evening in the Carriage with the Ladies and Johnson Hellen.
20. IV:15— Walk to the Slashes— Blackberries— Garden— Evening ride with John

Mr Weightman informed me, that he came to take leave of me in his capacity as Mayor of the City; and to tender his thanks to me, for my attention to the objects which he has from time to time laid before me in that character— He has been chosen Cashier of the Bank of Washington, and the duties of that office are incompatible with those of Mayor— Mr Brent came with Andrew Armstrong, heretofore commercial agent of the United States at the Island of Hayti— He has been recalled in consequence of the refusal of President Boyer, and his Government to recognize him as the Agent, unless he should be formally accredited in that character— This has been declined on our part, as implying a recognition of the Independence of the Haytian Government. Armstrong has been there several years with an informal character in which they acquiesced until recently when the French and English Governments have appointed Consuls General to reside there. Since which President Boyer will hold no intercourse with an informal agent from the United States. Dr Watkins called and shewed me some remarks which he proposes to publish in the National Journal, with the extract from my Letter to L. Harris of 16. Novr 1814. Charles Pierce, the young man from Boston who applies for a Midshipman’s warrant came again, and said he had made his application, and delivered his recommendations to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Southard was afterwards here, and promised to grant the warrant. He had despatches from Commodore Rodgers dated 30. May at Gibraltar, whence he sailed the next day, to return home by the way of the West-Indies. He expects Rodgers will arrive with the North-Carolina, about the last of this Month at New-York; and urged me if I should at that time be at New-York, to go on board of her— He had also a Letter from Mr Joshua Sands, about the Navy Yard controversy at Brooklyn— More moderate than some of its predecessors. Mr Rush also was here; and took a Letter he had left with me from a Mr Bry at Ouachita in Louisiana, and a statement respecting Silk-worms, and the cultivation of the white mulberry tree— I mentioned to Mr Rush some of the observations we had made upon the few worms that we had last Month, and which shew that there is much to be done in the management of them, which experience alone can teach— Mary Roberdeau left us and returned home— I rode after dinner round by the Capitol and College with John. The heat was so oppressived that I could not write in the Evening.
21. IV:30. Shower Bath— Walk to the Slashes— Blackberries. Garden.

Mr Southard came to introduce, as an old College companion of his, Mr Robertson of Pittsburg, Pennsylvania. Dr Sewall spoke of the recent Meeting of the Committee on the Affairs of the Columbian College; the result of which he said had been published in the Columbian Star, a Newspaper formerly edited in this City, in connection with the College, but now transferred to Philadelphia— He said this Committee had determined that the debts of the College should be paid— That Luther Rice and Obadiah B. Brown should retire from all management of the Affairs of the College, and that a Baptist Clergyman in Virginia named Dr Semple, the most eminent man of the Baptist denomination in the Union, should come and reside here as the President of the College— He said that all confidence had been lost in Rice and Brown as managers of pecuniary concerns, and that was not all— It does not appear that any measures have yet been taken to raise the funds for paying the debts— Dr. Sewall mentioned that he had a Letter from Dr Coney, who wished to see me, and would visit Boston and Quincy when I shall be there— J. Q. A. Boyd made his appearance here this day— I saw him only on horseback in the yard. I had also a visit from Mr Cambreleng, who is here from New York—he says on business— I rode in the Carriage after dinner with Mary Hellen and Charles. The day and Evening were cool; but Mary Hellen; both my Sons and myself are still drooping in health—
Of the seeds and stones which on the 18th. and 19th. of June I planted in two Quart Glass Tumblers the Orange seeds alone have vegetated— Six or seven of them have put out radicles and there are two from one seed which have been stretching down from day to day till they have reached the bottom of the tumbler and are now upwards of four inches long— It put out one stem the 17th. and a second is now heaving up at the surface— This seed was barely covered with the earth, and is now just at the edge, with its roots and its stems shooting from its sides— Other seeds were pressed deeper, and their vegetation is much slower— The taproots are visible all round the sides of the glass— I took up this day the Apricot Stone with two kernels, which I had planted in Seedling pot N. 6. on the 28th. of June. One of the kernels had begun to germinate, and shewed both a radicle and a plume— I replaced it, not so deep as it was; being now convinced that seed should be barely under light ground.
22. IV:30— Sun rose 4:47. Shower bath

Heard Mr Little from Matthew 13.23 [“]But he that received seed into the good ground is he that heareth the word and understandeth it; which also beareth fruit, and bringeth forth, some an hundred fold some sixty, some thirty.” The doctrine urged was the duty of Christians not only to hear, but to understand the word— And also of bearing fruit, in which he observed that the text admitted of degrees— This is true— The Spirit of the gospel does admit degrees of merit, but does not countenance degrees of virtue, and manifestly imports entire equality of reward, and of punishment— Mr Little gave notice that the intermission of the evening service still continued— Mr Peter Hagner the third Auditor paid me a visit after the morning service— And mentioned that he proposed shortly to make an excursion from the City— Heard Mr Baker in the afternoon— He read the 48th. Psalm, and instead of a Sermon, read the pastoral Letter from the Presbyterian Convention recently assembled at Philadelphia, to the Christian denomination of that sect throughout the United States— It speaks with high gratification of several revivals of religion, which it affirmed have occurred, and denounced in very forcible language the prevailing vice of intemperance— Mr Baker added a most earnest exhortation of his own to the sharp rebuke of the Convention— He said it was computed that in the United States there are a hundred thousand professed drunkards, and that thirty thousand of them die every year— I think he fell far short of the real number of drunkards, and exaggerated the number of deaths among them— Drunkards shorten their lives, yet many of them live to old age, and nothing like the proportion of three in ten of them die every year— If all who shorten their lives by the abuse of ardent Spirits were included under the name of drunkards, half a million would be much nearer the account than one hundred thousand— Of the half a Million probably more than thirty thousand die yearly and they die in larger proportion than the temperate— Mr Baker highly commended the Society for the promotion of Temperance recently formed in Boston, and warmly urged the adoption of the rule recommended by them, of abstaining entirely from the use of ardent Spirits except medicinally. He said that two entire religious congregations in Boston had adopted this practice and were adhering to it. He compared the wives of Drunkards to the Indian widows who burn themselves to death upon the funeral pile of their husbands, but said their condition was worse, because the dead body could at least not curse his wife— Mr Baker was intensely earnest in his exhortation— Would to God that anything could be devised to suppress that odious, disgusting and fatal vice of intemperance— This day was cool with an Eastern wind. This evening I rode in the Carriage with Mary and Johnson Hellen, and with Charles. John was unwell— The second stem from one Orange seed in the glass Tumbler N. 1. this day came up at the side of the glass— The first stem has risen just above the edge of the Tumbler, spread out its two opening leaves, and put forth a third— The Orange seed does not come up out of the ground— My two apple trees yet live the transplanted one is shewing the eighth leaf, but there is no perceptible growth in them from one day to another
23. IV:30— Shower and tub bath— Slashes— Blackberries— North-east Storm— Rainy day.

My river baths continue necessarily to be intermitted. I walked this morning as usual towards the College, but the rain soon came on, and continued great part of the day— Wyer called and brought me an extraordinary pair of English Razors. Mr Weightman came and introduced Mr Joseph Gales junr as Mayor of the City; his Successor—chosen by the Boards of Aldermen and Common Council; to continue in service until the biennial election to be held next June— Mr Brent came for an order of remission of the penalty for Thomas Emory, Master of the American Brig Tom, which I gave him—and with it a similar order to remit a penalty, with forfeiture of the vessel incurred by Joseph Swift, Master of the Schooner Swift of New Bedford, a case under peculiar circumstances, and which although coming within the positive provisions of the law, is not within the reasons for which it was enacted— Mr Wirt the Attorney General, just returned from Annapolis introduced a friend of his Mr Gilmer from Virginia. I sent for Mr Elgar, and informed him that the guard of Marines, who have had the nightly custody of the Capitol must be discontinued, there not being a sufficient number of the men belonging to the corps to keep it up; and advised him to engage watchmen to take care of the building— He supposed four men would be necessary and sufficient— The number of marines of the guard has been eight— I spoke also of the penitentiary cells of which he said there were to be 160, 3 1/2 feet wide and 8 feet long— All of the same size— He said the Corporation of Alexandria had remonstrated against cells of nearly the same dimensions, as being too small— They had therefore at the gaol there been reduced in number, and enlarged in size— I asked him if a certain portion of the cells at the Penitentiary could not be so reduced and enlarged. He said he would consult with Mr Bulfinch and make report to me concerning it— I took up a second time the Apricot Stone planted in Seedling Pot N. 5. on the 23d of June— No vegetation. Nor has there been any of either cherry, plum or Apricot that I have planted this Summer. It seems as if they must all pass a Winter, before they will vegetate— I found on comparing the Pennsylvania Walnuts, and the Cherry plum and Apricot Stones that I have kept in sand with those that I have packed in fresh earth, that sand does not, and earth does keep them of specific gravity to sink in water
24 IV:30— Walk to the Slashes— Blackberries. Garden— Rain.

Mr Brent came and mentioned that Mrs Sumter, wife of the Minister heretofore to Brazil, had lately been here, and made application respecting the Settlement of her husband’s Accounts— He had a copy of a Letter from the late President Monroe to me dated 29. June 1821 at Oak-hill, in answer to one from me to him of the preceding day; but there was no copy of my Letter to Mr Monroe at the Department— I found it in my Letter Book, and furnished a copy of it to Mr Brent— Mrs. Sumter’s object is to obtain the cancelment of a charge appearing against her husband at the Treasury. Major Nourse, brought a Letter from a Missionary to the Choctaw Indians, desiring an application of a part of the funds from the 54. Sections of Lands the proceeds from the Sales of which are reserved for them, to the Education of two Choctaw Youths, at the University in Ohio— Bishop having offered to educate one gratuitously— I observed to Major Nourse that the application must be made authentically from the Choctaws themselves, in which case there would be no difficulty— But they must specify by name the youths whom they wished to have educated— Mr Rush came with an Application from Alexander Alexander Master of the British Ship Thomas Ritchie, for remission of a penalty, for bringing an excess of Passengers, which I granted— It was a second case of a British Ship measuring less Tonnage at our Custom-house, than was shewn by her British Register. Mr Rush asked also for the return of the Letters of Dr Mease and Dr Bigelow respecting the introduction of exotic Plants. I gave
him those I had, and also a memorandum of enquiries to be annexed to the circular and list of plants to be forwarded to the consuls— I received a Letter from Henry Bird, late a Cadet at West-Point, and recently dismissed for deficiency, complaining of this sentence and appealing from it to me claiming as part right, part favour, to be reinstated for another trial— I sent the Letter to General Macomb, requesting to see him concerning it— He brought the semiannual reports since 1825 when Bird entered— They shewed a regular decline of his standing from about the middle down to near the bottom of his Class— And the reports of his conduct are unfavourable— I desired Genl. Macomb to enclose Bird’s Letter to Coll. Thayer, and request a Report from him on the case; and according to that Report to answer Bird’s Letter, informing him by my direction of the result— I signed an Exequatur for Charles Augustus Davis, as Consul General of the king of Saxony— I found this morning some of the Plums on the garden trees, bursting ripe and a fine fruit— The high Blackberries are beginning to dry up on the bushes— I have kept a small tin box full of cherry stones in sand, since the fruit was ripe— They all sank in water, when I put them up; but this day on taking them out, they almost all floated, when first put into the water— After soaking some time however, most of them sunk— Cherry-stones, I infer, will not keep in dry sand, but must be kept in moist earth—The same of Apricots and Plums— A third Orange Stem came up at the side of my Glass Tumbler N. 1. Its radicle had already reached the bottom of the Tumbler— T. B. Johnson embarked for France.
25. IV:30. Slashes— Blackberries— Garden— Showery.

Johnson Hellen and my Son John left us this morning in the Stage for Baltimore— They are going upon an excursion to Long Branch— This was the third showery day in succession, but without further appearance of vegetation among my plants— Mr Dickins came to enquire of the forms of certificate and devises of a Seal for the Columbian Institute I gave him my ideas concerning them, and he took those he had left with me— Dr Watkins introduced to me Lewis Barney—Brother of the member from Baltimore, and of the Collector of that Port. He told me he had attended the Convention, which sat there yesterday and the day before, of friends to the Administration— At one O’Clock Don Francisco Tacon, was introduced to me by Mr Daniel Brent, Chief Clerk of the Department of State, and delivered to me a Credential Letter from the King of Spain, as his Minister Resident to the United States— He addressed me in French, in a short speech containing the usual assurances that he was expressly commanded by his Sovereign to declare his friendly dispositions towards the United States and their Government, and his earnest desire to maintain the best understanding and the most harmonious relations with them— To which I answered by reciprocal assurances; desiring him to make known to his Sovereign the high satisfaction with which I had received these testimonials of his regard for the Nation and Government of this Union, and the determination on my part to meet them with a similar return— That so long as I should remain in the public service it would be my most anxious wish to continue upon terms of the most cordial intercourse with Spain, and I should use every exertion in my power to contribute to that end— He replied he was sure that the king of Spain would take great satisfaction in the Report which he should make to him of this assurance from me— He then delivered to me also the kings Answer to the Letter of recredence delivered to him by Mr Hugh Nelson— This as well as the credential Letter was dated in July 1825— He has been waiting since then in France— He said that having been informed of the absence of Mrs. Adams from the City, he should wait for return, to ask the favour for himself and his wife of being presented to her: and observed that he had left her at Bristol in Pennsylvania— I signed yesterday and this day 518 Land-grants, and 70 Patents
26. IV:15.— Slashes. Garden— Rain— Clear.

Mr Wytle came and announced himself as the person to whom my Son John had engaged to rent the Columbian Mills, and informed me that he could not comply with his engagement; which was to rent the Mills for a year for 1200 dollars, on condition that they should be put in complete repair, which is doing, and will cost more than a year’s rent— He said the person upon whom he had relied to furnish the money to carry on the business had died; and he now wanted capital— But he now proposed that I should furnish the money, and after the deduction of the Rent, to divide the profits— I told him that my Son John had the entire management of all the concerns of the Mills— That whatever he had to say upon the subject it would be well he should write to him; but that he need not trouble himself to make this last proposition, as it certainly would not be accepted— The Revd. Mr Hawley came and introduced a Mr of the neighbourhood of Troy, New-York. Wyer called and told me some of the vagaries of J. Q. A. Boyd, who is at Williamson’s Tavern. Mr Knapp came to enquire, if I had certain Books which might elucidate the literary History of this Country antecedent to the Revolution. I have no such books here, but had a desultory conversation of half an hour with him on the subject. Mr Calvert came merely to pay a morning visit— Coll. Trumbull to mention that he had now done retouching his four Pictures at the Capitol. There is nothing left for him to do he says but the varnishing; which must be done in cooler weather— He therefore proposes to return here, and put the finishing hand to his work, next November. He complains however of the Room: of the Light, and of the circular hole in the centre of the Rotundo, which he thinks will prove an insupportable nuisance— Mr Brent called, and also sent me a number of Blanks from the Department of State previous to my departure— Mr Wirt the Attorney General came to recommend that Captain Hills an Officer in the Army, who has been ordered to St. Louis, might receive an order for some employment which may retain him in this neighbourhood— For this he assigned several reasons— I told him I had no sort of objection, provided it should be compatible with the rules of the service, and with Justice to other Officers—for which I must refer him to Major Nourse at the War Department, and to Coll. Jones the Adjutant General— I said I thought all the reasons assigned by him rather weak upon which he said Hills had a matrimonial project in his mind, which I admitted was a very good reason, and to favour which I would comply as far as my own duty would allow— Dr Watkins came for the Letter from Benjamin Ames which he had left with me and which I returned to him—recommending a person named Work to be keeper of a new Light-House in the State of Maine— Mr Rush was here, and I had further Conversation with him, respecting the measures for introducing exotic Plants: and he read me a copy of his Letter to Mr Gallatin, requesting him to procure the Models of some new machinery invented for the manufacture of Silk. He returned me my Memorandum of enquiries to be transmitted with the Circulars to the Consuls; of which he has had a copy taken— I gave this day an order for the discharge from prison of Goulman Smither, a debtor of the United States in Virginia— Took my last walk for the Season to the Slashes. The Blackberries are drying on the bushes. I have still a curiosity to know what would be the effect upon them of cultivation— I planted in my eastern bed, 12 plum stones from the trees in the Garden— They had fallen from the trees since the rain, ripe and the plums burst open—there were no worms in them— They are the black muscle, Ouseley says the best of all plum trees for Stocks; and a very fine fruit. I am putting up a box of Nuts, Stones and seeds, in Sand to send to Quincy— I signed this Evening 296 Blank Sea Letters after taking a ride to the Eastern Branch with Mary Hellen and Charles.
27. IV:15. Sun rose 4:52. Garden. Boat Bath with Antoine— Swam from the Bridge.

Began the day with my Garden walk, and planted a row of 36. Black muscle plum stones from plums fallen from the trees and cracked. Those that remain whole on the trees have about ten days more to ripen. I planted also another row of whole black currents taken from the bushes; with several dried gooseberries and some old pear seeds— Two shoots pierced through the surface of my Tumbler N. 2. which I suppose came from a stray Orange seed. There have come up almost in Every instance two stems from each seed of that fruit— Mr Brent brought me the letter from Mr Thomas Sumter junr to Mr Monroe of 18. February 1825—which I had requested him to find on the files of the Department of State. Mr Anderson the Comptroller called, to ask for a Letter signed by him and the 5th. Auditor Pleasonton, in answer to certain enquiries I had addressed to them respecting the Settlement of my Accounts for public service abroad— There was some slight alteration or rather addition which he wished to make to it; and he promised to send me another correct copy of it to-morrow— Major Nourse brought me the proceedings of a Court Martial, held at West-Point upon two Cadets, Charles W. Rees, and Stockton John Stuart— He also asked also for my decisions on the two trials of Lieutenant Schuler, which I had however not written— He said he had a Letter from Governor Barbour, who expected to be here the latter end of next week— Mr Wolf Tone late a Captain in the army came to tell me that he was going immediately to New-York to bring his wife and child here.
